moves.1. g3 d5 2. Bg2 c6 3. d3 Nf6: 3... P-KN3 can also be played here.
moves.4. Nd2 g6 5. Ngf3 Bg7 6. O-O O-O: Bilek has a slight advantage in development, with 1 Q-side piece out already.
moves.7. e4 Bg4 8. Re1 Na6 9. e5: Bilek decides to go on the offensive.
moves.9... Nd7 10. h3 Bxf3 11. Nxf3 Nc7: Malich's pieces are in retreat. Bilek has a growing spatial advantage.
moves.12. h4 f5 13. exf6 e.p. exf6: Now Malich's Pawns are split and he has a weakness on the King file.
moves.14. Bf4 Rf7 15. Qd2 Nf8 16. Bh3: Bilek is slowly tightening his grip on the position.
moves.16... a5 17. a4 d4 18. Bxc7 Rxc7: Malich must do something to dispute Bilek's control of the board and K file, or he will be squeezed to death.
moves.19. Be6+ Kh8 20. Qf4 c5 21. Bc4: Bilek's attack is gathering steam. Malich can to nothing but wait for the inevitable.
moves.21... Re7 22. Rxe7 Qxe7: Malich hopes to break the attack by exchanging down.
moves.23. Re1 Qd7 24. Bb5: Bilek prepares for the final breakthrough.
moves.26. Bc4 Qc6 27. Ne5: The final blow. If Malich tries 27...PxN, 28 Q-B7! is immediately decisive.
moves.27... g5 28. Nf7+: Malich resigns, as his position is untenable.

players: Istvan Bilek (Hungary) vs. Burkhard Malich (East Germany)
